race.name: Trans Iowa
race.tagline: 300+ mile self-supported Iowa gravel ultra-distance challenge.

climate.description: Variable spring conditions with cold, wind, and rain possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through rolling Iowa farmland. 300+ miles self-supported with moderate elevation over extreme distance.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: 300+ mile self-supported ultra-distance. Extreme challenge but flat farmland terrain and small field.

biased_opinion.summary: Trans Iowa is a 300+ mile self-supported ultra-distance gravel race—one of the most extreme challenges in gravel racing. The self-supported format means no aid stations, no support, just you and 300+ miles of Iowa farmland. The ultra-distance reputation is legit, but it's flat farmland terrain with a small field. Checkpoint is rural Iowa with limited amenities. This is for ultra-distance purists seeking an extreme test.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: An extreme 300+ mile self-supported ultra-distance challenge. Worth it for ultra-distance purists seeking the ultimate test. Not for everyone—this is flat farmland with no support for 24-36 hours.

final_verdict.one_liner: 300+ mile self-supported Iowa farmland gravel ultra-distance.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you want an extreme 300+ mile self-supported ultra-distance challenge—yes, it's a legitimate test. If you want terrain variety or support—look elsewhere.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better ultra-distance events: Unbound 200, Dirty Kanza. For similar self-supported events: other ultra-distance self-supported races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Checkpoint has very limited lodging. Des Moines or nearby towns have options.
logistics.food: Rural area with limited dining. Self-supported format requires full nutrition planning.

course_description.character: Flat to rolling farmland gravel for 300+ miles self-supported.
course_description.signature_challenge: 300+ mile self-supported distance through Iowa farmland.
course_description.ridewithgps_name: Trans Iowa V8 Race 04/28/2012 Grinnell, IA

non_negotiables.why: 300+ miles self-supported requires extensive ultra-distance preparation and back-to-back-to-back long rides.
Self-supported format requires navigation, mechanical, and nutrition self-sufficiency.
Iowa spring means cold exposure for 24-36 hours.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 300+ miles of self-supported Iowa farmland gravel.

logistics.explanation: Guitar Ted kept logistics deliberately rough—secret routes until race day, cue sheet navigation only, and checkpoints in random parks with volunteers tracking riders. Greg Gleason describes the whole event as 'like a train wreck in many ways. You can see the imminent disaster coming from a long ways off.' The anti-logistics were intentional, designed to test problem-solving without race support. As Guitar Ted [ELITE/Race Director] puts it: "Most every Iowa gravel road has a 'street sign' on the corner of intersections. When this isn't the case, (Rare), we will mark a corner with flags."

length.explanation: 320-340 miles in 34 hours with zero support created proper suffering. Greg Gleason and Walter needed convenience store fuel stops every 100+ miles: 'Mountain Dew, fried pies, pizza, and topping off our water bottles.' Even in the favorable conditions of V12, only 55% finished versus the typical 15-20% rate. This wasn't just long—it was 'carry county maps in case you get lost' long. Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands. As Greg Gleason puts it: "Not knowing where and how far the next convenience store was, I started planning when it would be best for Walter and me to knock on a farmhouse door and ask for water."

technicality.explanation: Iowa gravel roads don't require advanced bike handling—the challenge was navigating by cue sheets in darkness and dealing with conditions. Kate Ankofski found 'riding at night, alone' required focus on 'pedaling up hills you can't see, guided solely by a few hundred lumens.' Technical difficulty came from conditions and paper navigation, not terrain demanding bike skills. Less technical than The Mid South. As Greg Gleason puts it: "With 75 miles to go to the finish, Walter and I put on a couple of extra layers and headed back onto the dark windy gravel."

elevation.explanation: Iowa's rolling farmland provided steady climbs but nothing mountainous—roughly 9,000 feet over 320 miles. Greg Gleason noted the final 75 miles featured 'steep, freshly graveled hilltops that headed directly into the south-east wind.' Guitar Ted warned riders would be 'either going up or down, and doing that over and over, ad infinitum,' but at corn-growing elevations. Less climbing than The Mid South. As Greg Gleason puts it: "With 75 miles to go to the finish, Walter and I put on a couple of extra layers and headed back onto the dark windy gravel."

climate.explanation: Late April in Iowa delivered the worst of Midwest spring weather—V2, V4, V6, and V11 were all truncated or affected by brutal conditions. Rain turned the B-roads into impassable mud that could 'swallow riders whole,' while cold and wind made the 34-hour exposure dangerous. The weather wasn't just uncomfortable, it was race-ending. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Greg Gleason puts it: "Not knowing where and how far the next convenience store was, I started planning when it would be best for Walter and me to knock on a farmhouse door and ask for water."

altitude.explanation: This is Iowa farmland at agricultural elevations. Altitude simply wasn't a factor in Trans Iowa's difficulty equation—the suffering came from distance, weather, and self-sufficiency, not thin air affecting performance.

adventure.explanation: Trans Iowa delivered pure adventure racing—secret routes, paper navigation, complete self-sufficiency, and real consequences. Jeff Kerkove witnessed riders 'sitting quietly in a convenience store staring with eyes glazed over onto a slice of pizza covered in Cheetos.' Kate Ankofski learned how badly she wanted this during mile-long portage sections through B-road mud. This was gravel's last truly wild race.

prestige.explanation: Trans Iowa earned cult status as gravel's original sufferfest—14 years of breaking souls before most people knew what gravel racing was. V2's zero finishers and the mystique around Guitar Ted's deliberately rough organization built legend status among the hardcore. It never cracked mainstream awareness like Unbound, capping its prestige at underground classic rather than household name.

race_quality.explanation: Race quality was intentionally rough around the edges—secret routes until race day, cue sheets only, zero support, and weather that regularly forced truncations (V4, V6, V11). Guitar Ted ran it like a rogue adventure, not a polished production. When 19 of 95 finished the final edition and multiple years saw single-digit finishers, you're looking at organized chaos more than refined racing.

experience.explanation: This was gravel's vision quest—340 miles of Iowa farmland with nothing but cue sheets and your ability to suffer through 34 hours. Rolling through small towns at 3 AM, navigating by paper in the dark, buying gas station burritos as your lifeline creates memories that outlast any medal. The complete self-sufficiency and secrecy made every edition feel like you were part of something underground.

community.explanation: Trans Iowa built a tight cult around the 'TI Family' who understood the specific madness of Iowa B-roads and peanut butter mud. Guitar Ted's pre-race steakhouse gathering and the shared suffering created camaraderie among the 100-rider cap. But the community stayed deliberately small—never growing beyond the hardcore willing to risk everything on unmarked roads.

field_depth.explanation: With only 100 riders max and frequent single-digit finish rates, the field was shallow but absolutely committed. V10's record 106 starters was the peak, but most years saw far fewer willing to attempt the full distance. The no-entry-fee policy attracted dedicated sufferers rather than casual participants, creating quality over quantity in the small field. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Greg Gleason puts it: "Sarah leaned over to me and said, 'Time to pick up the pace.' With that signal the race started."

value.explanation: Free entry made Trans Iowa unbeatable on paper value—340 miles of organized suffering for zero dollars. But the hidden costs were brutal: potential bike destruction on B-roads, mandatory self-sufficiency gear, and the real possibility of spending your weekend DNF'd in Iowa mud. You got exactly what you paid for: pure adventure with zero amenities.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $100-200. No entry fee meant your biggest costs were getting to Grinnell and having someone ready to extract you from rural Iowa when things went wrong. Accommodation was cheap in small-town Iowa, and gas station resupply kept food costs minimal during the race. The catch was gear—you needed everything from navigation to emergency supplies since zero support was the whole point. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
